title.rendered: GEAR A Soundbar That Makes Explosions Rain Down From Above 9 HOURS

content.rendered:
IF YOU’VE BEEN to a nice movie theater in the past few years, you’ve probably felt like the audio was coming from all around you—swooping overhead, moving left to right and behind you, all in sync with the onscreen action.

Theaters equipped with the latest Dolby Atmos and DTS:X sound systems use dozens of speakers all around the theater—even in the ceiling. They also employ special audio mixes to better tie sound effects to video action. The combination of speaker placement and sound engineering creates a unique harmony of motion between sound and vision.

That same effect would be a cool addition to your home theater, but few people want to embed a bunch of speakers in their ceiling. The next best thing is probably Samsung’snew Dolby Atmos home system, which packs that same dramatic effect into a traditional soundbar, a pair of wireless rear speakers, and a subwoofer. It uses the same hardware-based decoding tech as big theater rigs, so when you’re watching a Dolby Atmos-mastered movie, you get to take advantage of the same object-based sound engineering found in the cineplex.

Audio Acrobatics

The HW-K950 system simulates the effect of having speakers embedded in your ceiling. And does a remarkable job too, thanks to four upwards-firing 2.5-inch drivers—two on the soundbar and one on each of the rear speakers. The unique speaker design rebounds sound off of the ceiling and down toward your head, and it really does sound like things are raining down from on high.

The soundbar has left-center-right channels like any other unit out there, but the upward-firing speakers represent two more channels. There are two more “overhead” channels in the wireless rear speakers, as well as two more traditional channels. So while there are just four units in the package, Samsung cheekily bills it as a 5.1.4 system: Five surround-sound channels, one subwoofer, and four channels that bounce audio off your ceiling.

All told, there’s a whopping 500 watts of power spread across the whole system—about 25 times the power of your average TV’s built-in speakers. A 160-watt amp in the 8-inch sub, nine 2.5-inch drivers spread across the soundbar and rear speakers, and a 35mm wide-range tweeter in the soundbar unit. That makes it nearly four times as powerful as the only other Atmos-friendly soundbar we’ve seen, theYamaha YSP-5600.

Feed It Right

While Samsung says the system will “upmix” audio from non-Atmos sources to give it the around-and-above treatment, it’s better if you pick gear and content from the Atmos world. You’ll need a source that can decode and output Dolby Atmos content, which could be a Blu-ray player, receiver, game console, TV, PC, or streaming box. You’ll also need Dolby Atmos-mastered content, which Samsung says will be available on Blu-ray, 4K Blu-ray, and services such as Vudu, Netflix, and Amazon. You can getAtmos-mastered titles on Blu-ray right now like Mad Max: Fury Road, Game of Thrones, and The Fifth Element.

Soundbars are usually a cheap way to upgrade your home-theater audio experience, but this Atmos-enabled system is an exception. The HW-K950 is priced at $1,500 and will go on sale this summer, while a step-down HW-K850 system will sell for $1,000. While the lower-priced HW-K850 has the same upward-facing speakers in the soundbar, the wireless rear speakers aren’t part of the package.

title.rendered: Some Can Draw Bikes From Memory. Some … Definitely Can’t

content.rendered:
GO GRAB A pen and some paper and try this: Using only your memory, draw a bicycl
e. You have two minutes.

Gianluca Gimini has over the past six years asked more than 500 people to do exactly this. Drawing a bicycle from memory is harder than it sounds; of the 370 people who really tried (Gimini says a lot of people go rogue, when they realize their drawings aren’t turning out right), about 25 percent managed to accurately sketch a bike.

Gimini doesn’t pay attention to the accurate drawings in his illustration project Velocipedia. Instead, he created digital renderings of some of the weirdest, most impractical designs that came from the other 75 percent of the test group. “People draw some really crazy stuff when they are trying to be totally non-creative and just follow a task,” he says.

The idea started with a conversation in a bar in Bologna, Italy, in 2009. Gimini was recounting a childhood memory about a classmate who was asked to draw a bicycle, on the spot, in front of the entire class. He couldn’t, which seemed laughable. After all, bicycles are ubiquitous objects that most kids learn to ride at a young age. It’s a machine that’s been passed down generations, and its utility transcends geography and culture. “We both agreed that [everyone] knows how a bike is made,” Gimini says. “But then [my friend] tried to draw one on a napkin, and he failed.”

Gimini’s experiment isn’t the first of its kind. A psychologist from the University of Liverpool even conducted a test that challenged people to draw a bicycle from memory. And you may remember that BuzzFeed article from 2013, “Here’s What Happens When You Ask People To Draw A Map Of The USA From Memory.” (What happens is people can’t do it.)

Both surveys, while funny, made humans look like clueless morons. Gimini’s project doesn’t do that. By putting an artistic spin on the drawings, his project is instead a celebration of the ways people can be accidentally creative. In this way, it’s similar to a project that made the rounds online in 2014, when a high school student in San Antonio, Texas, asked strangers to draw a map of the world. He used Photoshop to create a composite map using 30 maps he collected in the survey. His assignment, according to The Atlantic, was to create “a piece of art that would reveal something unseen.” The result was a Rorschach inkblot that fused 30 perspectives into one graphic.

Gimini’s life-like illustrations have a similar charm, like you’re peering into a hidden nook of someone’s imagination. “A single designer could not come up with so many variations on a single theme if he worked on it all his life,” Gimini says.
